newsitem.title: INDIA: India tribal guerrillas kill 13 in night attack.
newsitem.headline: India tribal guerrillas kill 13 in night attack.

text.p: Tribal militants attacked two villages in northeastern India killing 13 people and wounding eight, police said on Saturday.
Bodo guerrillas shot the victims on Friday night in Nalbari district, about 50 km (30 miles) west of Guwahati, the largest city in Assam state.
The dead included five women, they said.
Police in Guwahati said the insurgents also set several houses on fire in the villages before fleeing.
"The victims were called out of their houses and indiscriminately fired upon," an Assam police official told Reuters.
The attacks were the latest in a mounting campaign of violence in the northeast, where dozens of militant groups are fighting Indian rule across several states.
The state government of Assam has imposed an indefinite curfew in areas where the killings occurred.
More than one thousand people have been killed since 1985 in violence linked to a Bodo ethnic movement for a separate province. A small group is also fighting for independence.
Officials said they could not immediately say which community the victims belonged to.
Bodo tribal militants usually target Bengali-speaking Hindu settlers in their traditional homeland.
Security officials said they had begun combing the area for the guerrillas.
The rebels have stepped up the attacks to coincide with the 50th anniversary of Indian independence, which was celebrated on Friday.
Separatist groups observed a general strike on Friday, with a call to boycott the celebrations.
On Friday, militants killed four people in Assam and two others in nearby Tripura state.
The militants say the Indian government has neglected the region's needs and exploited its economic resources.
